column2: Trish has never been seen in public before. Nor have Sharon, Janet, Debbie, Denise, Donna, Jacqui, Joanne, Kim, Lorraine, Mandy, Paula, Sandra or Tina. But for the next two weeks, these 14 artworks by the pop star Robbie Williams and his creative partner Ed Godrich will be on display at Sothebyâ€™s in central London. Their curious titles â€“ all womenâ€™s names that were popular back when Williams was a Stoke-on-Trent schoolboy â€“ are not the artworksâ€™ only common factor. The large-scale black and white images, the fruits of a five-year collaboration, are strikingly thematic. â€œRobbie and Ed refer to the paintings as a family of work,â€ said Hugo Cobb, a contemporary art specialist at Sothebyâ€™s. â€œThey are all created in the same visual language. But when you stand in front of them, you see they have a different character. Each picture definitely has a specific visual mood. â€œCoherence, ambition and authenticity are the three things I think of when I stand in front of these works.â€ Another painting from the same group, Beverly, was sold by Sothebyâ€™s last month for Â£40,000 â€“ double the top end of the pre-sale estimate â€“ to a private foundation in Central America. Williams said the pair were now â€œready to share our creative vision with the worldâ€. He wanted people to â€œfeel a sense of positivity â€¦ to be intrigued, to feel curious, and spot new characteristics every time they look back at each painting.â€ Using the moniker Williams Godrich, the collaborators painted the 14 works on huge polystyrene panels â€“ a medium that gives them a â€œunique textureâ€, said Cobb â€“ building up layers of detail. â€œAll the characters are in our head and come to life as the painting develops,â€ said Godrich. â€œSometimes a character will emerge by mistake, or part of a figurine will happen by chance because of the direction of a particular brushstroke. â€œRobbie might see something completely different when itâ€™s his turn to draw; thatâ€™s why our work takes on multiple narratives. Heâ€™ll add a bit and Iâ€™ll add a bit until we end up with a completely unique being.â€ According to Williams, the paintingsâ€™ titles came about because â€œwe like the obscurity of these names which were highly popular back in the day but are not so common now. For us they are names that define the 1980s, an influential era which has inspired our art.â€ In a Sothebyâ€™s video, he said his interest in art had been sparked by album covers. â€œI didnâ€™t realise they were art at the time, I was just intrigued by the images in front of me â€¦ So I guess my first love of art was through music.â€ He and Godrich had formed an â€œart bandâ€, he added. Art was â€œa great experiment for me to be creative in a different vehicleâ€. Williams, who has amassed a huge fortune from record sales and concerts, has built up a personal art collection. This year he sold two works by Banksy for a total of Â£7m. The sales were intended to free up space to be able to buy â€œnew art from new peopleâ€ and help fund his own work, he said. Cobb said the Williams Godrich debut was an exciting moment. â€œRobbie and Ed are very serious about this. This is not a one-off project â€“ theyâ€™ve put a huge amount of energy and time into their work. As to their future collectability, it remains to be seen.â€  Black and White Paintings by Robbie Williams and Ed Godrich is at Sothebyâ€™s, 35 New Bond Street, London W1S 2RP, until 25 May.
column4: Sothebyâ€™s debut of Robbie Williamsâ€™ art puts Sharon and Trish on show

column2: This atmospheric, noir-ish thriller is loosely based on the real life of American journalist Jake Adelstein (Ansel Elgort) who worked the Tokyo crime beat in the 90s. We begin with Adelstein facing down a roomful of extremely threatening criminals, then rewind a couple of years to learn his origin story. He is the first foreigner on the paper and instantly gains the nickname â€œMossadâ€ as itâ€™s assumed heâ€™s a Jewish spy. His ambition leads him into conflict but heâ€™s charismatic and tenacious. Michael Mannâ€™s direction of the pilot does a fine job of communicating both Adelsteinâ€™s fish-out-of-water status and the pressure-cooker intensity of his environment. Immersive.StarzPlay, from Sunday 15 May Lots of people look for an excuse to wriggle out of high school reunions. For the group of frenemies in this pacy, slightly overheated, bilingual thriller, the stakes are higher than usual. â€œAttend, or Iâ€™ll tell the police what happened on graduation nightâ€, says an anonymous text message. Set in Miami, it centres on events at a beach after graduation. The group â€“ high on life, alcohol and ecstacy â€“ decide on some late-night fun. What transpires will haunt them â€“ but will they pay a price two decades on? Oscar-nominated Roma star Marina de Tavira and Rosie Perez are among the handsome ensemble cast.Apple TV+, from Friday 20 May An odd and surprisingly effective dating show, The Future Diary is unscripted unreality but still attempts â€“ and somehow succeeds â€“ in establishing an affecting real-life narrative. The diary of the title is the pre-written story of Nakasone and Wakamatsuâ€™s relationship, with cues to follow and outcomes already determined. Against all the odds, it sort of works â€“ the emotion tends to override the formatting. In season two, a second male suitor is introduced and a love triangle develops. Who will Nakasone choose? And what does choice even mean in this context?Netflix, from Tuesday 17 May Imagine recreating the social and romantic dynamics of high school but in adulthood, with money at stake. Sounds positively nightmarish, right? Still, this competitive dating show aims to do exactly that, bringing together 15 UK contestants to play American teen drama archetypes in an impenetrable fog of pheromones and performative melodrama. Perhaps inevitably, Mean Girls star Lindsay Lohan narrates a show that has the potential to be the guiltiest of pleasures as the battle for Prom royalty commences.Amazon Prime Video, from Wednesday 18 May Some people really donâ€™t want their photograph taken. Argentinian business magnate Alfredo YabrÃ¡n â€“ whose various enterprises operated under the protective gaze of the countryâ€™s 1990s president, Carlos Menem â€“ was one of these. So when news photographer JosÃ© Luis Cabezas snapped the elusive tycoon on a beach in Argentinaâ€™s upmarket Pinamar coastal resort and dragged YabrÃ¡n into the light, he was setting in motion a deadly chain of events. Netflixâ€™s latest fascinating true-crime offering is a story of how pulling a single thread can unravel a whole garment.Netflix, from Thursday 19 May The magnificently unpredictable fantasy animation anthology produced by Deadpool director Tim Miller returns for a third season â€“ and perhaps the biggest compliment we can give it is to say that itâ€™s still hard to know what to expect. After all, previous seasons have veered between manga, stop-motion, photorealism and much more besides. Up to now thereâ€™s been little sense of narrative continuity, but this time we are promised the return of at least one familiar story â€“ the trio of post-apocalyptic robots. Tantalising. PHNetflix, from Friday 21 May Sissy Spacek and JK Simmons star in this intriguing drama about Irene and Franklin York, a couple who have discovered that a chamber in their yard leads to a deserted planet. Itâ€™s a secret theyâ€™ve guarded for years, but an enigmatic, anonymous man (Chai Hansen) arrives in their lives threatening disruption. Cleverly, what looks at first to be a slightly opaque sci-fi becomes much more than that â€“ a meditation on love, loss and the way answers to lifeâ€™s big questions arenâ€™t always found in obvious places.Amazon Prime Video, from Friday 21 May
column4: Tokyo Vice to Night Sky: the seven best shows to stream this week

column2: Good morning. The UK is holding negotiations with the EU about parts of the Brexit withdrawal agreement, and if that feels like deja vu, thatâ€™s because it is. After six years of deadlocks, impasses and stalemates, it feels like politics has gone back to square one. First, the Democratic Unionist party said it would not join the power-sharing assembly at Stormont without changes to the Northern Ireland Brexit protocol. Then foreign secretary Liz Truss said yesterday that unless the EU gives way she will have â€œno choice but to actâ€ during a â€œtetchyâ€ conversation with MaroÅ¡ Å efÄoviÄ, the vice-president of the European Commission. The decision to contest the protocol has caused some diplomatic alarm: the US is so concerned that it is sending an emergency delegation to London, the Guardian reports today. Officials in Brussels are said to be â€œflabbergastedâ€ and thereâ€™s even concern within Trussâ€™s own party. But at least one man is calm. In the Telegraph, former Brexit minister David Frost writes that Boris Johnson should just rip up the Northern Ireland Protocol â€“ and even compared it to the prime ministerâ€™s handling of the war in Ukraine. So. A lot going on. To make sense of it all, I spoke to the Guardianâ€™s Ireland correspondent, Rory Carroll. First, here are the headlines. Nato | Finland must apply to join Nato without delay, the countryâ€™s president and prime minister have said. After decades of military non-alignment, the Nordic country made the historic move in response to Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. Partygate | More than 100 fixed-penalty notices have now been handed out for breaches of lockdown rules in Downing Street and Whitehall, the Metropolitan police said. Boris Johnson is understood to not be among those in a new set of fines. Climate crisis | The worldâ€™s leading energy economist has warned against investing in â€œcarbon bombâ€ oil and gas developments. After the publication of a Guardian investigation, Fatih Birol of the IEA called for a â€œcleaner and more secure energy systemâ€. Covid | Six people have died amid an â€œexplosiveâ€ spread of fever, North Korean state media has announced, a day after it admitted for the first time ever that an outbreak of Covid had occurred. Politics | Boris Johnson has demanded that ministers reduce their staff to free up cash to spend on the cost of living crisis. 90,000 jobs in the civil service could be cut. Itâ€™s been over two years since Boris Johnson signed the EU withdrawal agreement, and celebrated an achievement which had eluded Theresa May. That victory was rooted in what he claimed was a â€œgreat dealâ€ for Northern Ireland â€“ a special arrangement which avoided a trade-and-customs border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland by putting one in the Irish Sea instead. The Northern Ireland protocol, as it became known, was presented by Johnson as conclusive. But always lurking was an uncertainty that has arisen again this week. Hereâ€™s a guide to whatâ€™s happening: Brexit is back â€“ again Not that it ever really went away. After a hiatus due to the war in Ukraine, negotiations with the EU about the protocol have resumed and foreign secretary Liz Truss has come out swinging, threatening to unilaterally scrap important sections of the protocol if the EU does not show the â€œrequisite flexibilityâ€. The EU has said previously that there will be severe and immediate consequences, at worst a trade war, if the UK were to go through with something like this. That would have serious consequences for the whole of the UK â€“ but especially Northern Ireland, where a new government is yet to form at Stormont after last weekâ€™s elections. Sinn FÃ©inâ€™s victory In a historic victory last week, Sinn FÃ©in became the biggest party in the Stormont assembly, winning 29% of the vote. Itâ€™s a seismic moment for the party, Rory Carroll says, because for the first time in Northern Irelandâ€™s 101-year history, a nationalist party has emerged triumphant. This victory is largely â€œsymbolic and psychologicalâ€, Rory explains, â€œand in the Northern Ireland context thatâ€™s really important: symbolism has an exaggerated impactâ€. Rory calls Sinn FÃ©inâ€™s victory â€œa wake up callâ€ for the DUP, because it will boost Sinn FÃ©inâ€™s campaign for a referendum on the unification of Ireland. â€œNot in the short term,â€ he adds. â€œWeâ€™re looking at least a medium term, five years, probably more before that may happen, if it happens.â€ For most people, however, life will continue as normal: â€œthis makes no real meaningful difference in the day to day because Sinn FÃ©in have been in government for 15 years in Northern Ireland and will continue to beâ€. Despite the importance politically for Sinn FÃ©inâ€™s leader to move from deputy first minister to putative first minister, the roles have identical powers. â€œOne canâ€™t order a toasted sandwich without the other signing off on that,â€ Rory says. So in practical terms, it should not make any difference to the running of Northern Ireland. But one part of the Brexit withdrawal agreement could derail that altogether. What is the Northern Ireland protocol? As the EU has border checks when certain goods, particularly food, arrive from non-EU countries, when the UK voted to leave there was a major problem â€“ what happens between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland? Putting a border in place would threaten the Good Friday Agreement, something both sides have stressed their commitment to protecting. And so the Northern Ireland protocol was born â€“ instead of border checks happening between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, they were to happen between Northern Ireland and Great Britain instead. It was an imperfect solution to an impossible problem, but the protocol was enshrined in international law. Rory wrote a great explainer on what it is, why it matters and what it will mean for the future of Northern Ireland. What does this mean for Northern Ireland? The Democratic Unionist party has two main problems with the Northern Ireland protocol, Rory tells me: itâ€™s hurting Northern Irelandâ€™s economy and it undermines its position in the UK, by creating a de facto border between Northern Ireland and Britain. And so, in response, the DUP has said that it will block the formation of a power-sharing administration unless Downing Street radically changes the protocol. If this were to happen, it would send Northern Ireland into a political crisis, creating what Rory has described as a â€œzombified form of local governmentâ€. Some ministers from the outgoing executive would stay on â€“ but with much reduced responsibilities and powers. â€œThey kind of keep the lights on, just about, but they cannot make any major decisions or launch new initiatives.â€ Northern Ireland is pretty familiar with this set up: in 2017 Sinn FÃ©in blocked power sharing over a dispute with the DUP and Stormont was suspended for three years. In January, it was the DUPâ€™s turn to press the stop button and suspend the executive. This means constraints on spending because thereâ€™s nobody to sign crucial budgetary decisions. A government that can barely function means that the public are left in the lurch: â€œNorthern Irelandâ€™s got a serious health care crisis,â€ Rory says, â€œitâ€™s got some of the worst waiting lists and health metrics in the UK. Thereâ€™s a consensus in Northern Ireland that healthcare is a disaster and needs urgent attention.â€ So when rumblings of another government shutdown surfaced, health care professionals started to panic. â€œWeâ€™ve had a joint statement from five medical organisations, including the British Medical Association Northern Ireland and the Royal College of GPs, where they are pleading with politicians in Northern Ireland to form an executive because if they donâ€™t, they say, it will compound the crisis in healthcare and will risk the lives of patients.â€ Rory tells me. â€œThatâ€™s how high the stakes are.â€ Itâ€™s a dilemma: on the one hand, a stable government in Northern Ireland depends on some revision to the Northern Ireland protocol. But on the other, threatening to withdraw unilaterally risks the economy for the entirety of the UK. And in the midst of all this political noise, one thing is clear: the people on the sharp end of this political paralysis are the public. While I admit a special personal interest in Electronic Arts losing the Fifa licence for football games, you donâ€™t need to share my nerdy predilections to find Keith Stuartâ€™s piece interesting â€“ just a curiosity about who wins in a battle between quality products and familiar brands, and why. Archie Cryptocurrency was supposed to level the playing field, it was supposed to democratise by decentralising power. But the jig is up David A Banks argues in this brilliant piece that examines the murky world of crypto and digital assets. Nimo Few subjects for the venerable Ranked series are more obviously compelling than Paul Verhoeven, and thereâ€™s only one question: is Showgirls a preposterous turkey or a camp masterpiece? Anne Billson decides. Archie I loved this piece by Raphael Rashid who spoke to photographer Kim Dong-hyun about the cool and stylish senior citizens of Seoul whoâ€™s wardrobes have endless flair. Nimo Daniel Trilling writes for the LRB on a book by Ciaran Thapar about his time as a youth worker in south London. The piece (like the book, by the sounds of it) is an indispensable examination of how preconceptions about â€œknife crimeâ€ harm the young Black men assumed to be the perpetrators. Archie Rebekah Vardy endured another day of cross-examination at the hands of Coleen Rooneyâ€™s barrister, David Sherborne, yesterday â€“ admitting that she knew her agent, Caroline Watt, had forwarded private information about Rooney to the Sun in the past, and accused of â€œthrowing her under the busâ€ to protect herself. Jim Waterson, reporting from the high court, witnessed Vardyâ€™s grilling â€“ including an excrutiating exchange about the nature of the watery grave her agentâ€™s mobile phone had ended up in, a rather terse response to an everyday colloquialism and a debate about the nature of the ğŸ˜‚ emoji. At one point Rooneyâ€™s barrister described a WhatsApp message in a conversation between Vardy and Watt that included the words â€œpoor Coleenâ€ followed by â€œlaughing emojisâ€. Vardy told the court she disputed this characterisation: â€œI donâ€™t know whether theyâ€™re laughing emojis.â€ The lawyer, in an apparent reference to the ğŸ˜‚ emoji, replied: â€œOK, crying with laughter.â€ Cricket | Brendon McCullum has been confirmed as the new coach of Englandâ€™s menâ€™s Test team. The New Zealander said he would look to â€œbring about changeâ€ in the dressing room after a long period of poor form. Football | Tottenham Hotspur beat Arsenal in a stunning victory last night by 3-0 to ensure the battle for the final Champions League spot will go to the wire. Golf | Amnesty International criticised Greg Norman for â€œseriously misguidedâ€ comments about the murder of Jamal Khashoggi. Norman, chief executive of a Saudi-backed golf investment firm, said of the killing: â€œweâ€™ve all made mistakesâ€. In the Guardian print edition today, the lead story is â€œUS team flies in amid fears over Northern Ireland dealâ€. The Express has â€œDefiant Truss â€¦ weâ€™ll rip up Brexit border dealâ€. The Telegraph says â€œFrost: PM must brave it out over protocolâ€ while the i splashes with â€œLords try to delay Truss from tearing up Brexit pactâ€. The Times has â€œTories risk losing next election, Hunt tells PMâ€ and says the former cabinet minister Jeremy Hunt wonâ€™t rule out a leadership bid. â€œThe home of UKâ€™s worst Covid law-breakersâ€ â€“ the Mirrorâ€™s verdict after more than 100 fines were issued for No 10 parties. The Daily Mail says â€œ91,000 civil service jobs will be axedâ€ after Boris Johnson ordered that one in five must go. â€œShot in the backâ€ â€“ the Metro leads on a Russian atrocity in Ukraine. The Financial Times leads on crypto: â€œTetherâ€™s peg to the dollar snaps as â€˜fragileâ€™ stablecoin market takes hitâ€. â€œSheâ€™s Dame Debsâ€ â€“ the Sun reports on the podcaster Deborah James receiving an honour for her account of having incurable bowel cancer. Our criticsâ€™ roundup of the best things to watch, read and listen to right now TVWill Young: Losing My Twin Rupert (Channel 4)This is a rare beast: a celebrity documentary that has an articulate subject, an affecting story and a sense of mission. Often, films in this genre induce an uncomfortable sense that the makers are exploiting grief. This, however, is an unflinching portrait of sadness that acknowledges the complexity around addiction. â€“ Lucy Mangan MusicThe Smile â€“ A Light for Attracting AttentionThereâ€™s no getting around the fact that the debut album from The Smile â€“ Thom Yorke, Jonny Greenwood and Tom Skinner of Sons of Kemet â€“ sounds exactly like Radiohead: more so than Yorkeâ€™s impressionistic, sketchy solo albums. Arguably thereâ€™s nothing head-spinningly different here, but you would have a hard time arguing that it isnâ€™t exceptionally good. â€“ Alexis Petridis FilmVortexGaspar NoÃ© brings his cauterisingly fierce gaze to the spectacle of old age. Here, death is the vortex: the dark focus, whose gravitational pull gets stronger â€“ and harder to avoid thinking about â€“ with every passing year. In showing us that death is chaotic â€“ like life â€“ this is a work of wintry maturity, and real compassion. â€“ Peter Bradshaw PodcastKermode & Mayoâ€™s TakeHaving escaped the BBC yoke, the UKâ€™s premier film grumps return with a sparkling new podcast. While it retains lots of the previous showâ€™s charm, theyâ€™re still finding their feet. And they have to read ads, which they obviously hate. Still, freedom, eh?â€“ Laura Snapes A campaign to widen access to the English countryside is gathering momentum. However, as Helena Horton reports from a mass trespass event in Devon, there is little sign the government is willing to budge. A bit of good news to remind you that the worldâ€™s not all bad A small Canadian town has become gripped by a mysterious horror-themed treasure hunt, with thousands of local people grappling with a succession of clues â€“ and the promise of a cash prize. Clues posted on Facebook by a shadowy figure calling themselves Roman Dungarvan are themed around the murder and apparent ghostly return of a 19th-century cook. â€œI donâ€™t think anything of this magnitude has ever happened in Miramichi,â€ said Adams Robichaud, a high school student. â€œAnd we just absolutely love it.â€ Sign up here for a weekly roundup of The Upside, sent to you every Sunday
column4: Friday briefing: How do you solve a problem like the Northern Ireland protocol?

column2: A review that criticised the format of Channel Nineâ€™s leadersâ€™ debate was spiked by Tory Maguire, the executive editor of Nine Entertainmentâ€™s newspapers the Sydney Morning Herald and the Age. Maguire has editorial control of the national content in the two mastheads, and she has confirmed she spiked the piece by senior culture writer Karl Quinn, but not for the reasons some staff feared. â€œThe original brief for Karlâ€™s piece, about how the shoutyness of the debate might alienate young viewers, ended up being very similar to a separately commissioned piece by Jess Irvine,â€ Maguire told Weekly Beast. â€œWe ended up with too many takes on one topic, which is something we try to avoid. We also covered commentary on the tone of the debate in our news coverage. Spiking stories is not that unusual, especially on a fast-moving news day when there are lots of people commissioning.â€ While Irvineâ€™s article did mention the debateâ€™s â€œgenerally ill-tempered toneâ€, it was largely an analysis of what was said from an economic perspective. After all, Irvine is an economics correspondent. Quinnâ€™s review tackled the debate as a piece of television, arguing it failed on several fronts as the men talked over each other. Sources say he filed it around midday on Monday and it never appeared. The two venerable newspapers, whose motto is â€œindependent alwaysâ€, teamed up with Nine News, 60 Minutes and 2GB for Sunday nightâ€™s television spectacle in what was a very public display of a sometimes uneasy media alliance formed in 2018, when Fairfax merged with Nine. â€œFor all the post-event pearl clutching from some commentators who disliked Sunday nightâ€™s heat-and-fury leadersâ€™ debate, Channel Nineâ€™s viewers seemed to find it compelling enough to stay the course.â€ https://t.co/Z2BVLkXOH6 â€œThis was the first time ever we have combined the power of Nine as the biggest media group in the country with the experience of Nineâ€™s journalists across our broadcast television, publishing, radio and digital platforms for this 60 Minutes special event,â€ Nineâ€™s news director Darren Wick told staff on Monday. â€œSarah Abo, from 60 Minutes, Chris Uhlmann from Nine News, Deborah Knight representing Nine Radio (3AW; 4BC, 2GB, 6PR) and David Crowe, from The Age and the Sydney Morning Herald made a formidable combination.â€ â€˜The complaint about the paltry â€œ60-second sliversâ€ featured in what ranks as the performance art piece of outrage thundered at Nineâ€™s debate by The Guardian.â€™ https://t.co/0P8lD1aKiZ Among the many critical voices was Nineâ€™s own 2GB broadcaster Ben Fordham: â€œIt wasnâ€™t great. It was a shambles. It was messy, disjointed, awkward. All over the shop.â€ He didnâ€™t go as far as the Guardianâ€™s Katharine Murphy, who was critical of the format, not the host, and wrote on Sunday night: â€œItâ€™s hard to find words for how terrible that second leadersâ€™ debate was. A genuine shit blizzard. It was the Jerry Springer of leadersâ€™ debates.â€ Nine's Great Debate audience peaked at 1.178 million and averaged 904,000. Another 70,000 on 9Now. Youtube accounts hit 814,000 engagements, Facebook, 1.2 million views and 250,000 views on Twitter. That does not include SMH and Age streaming or audiences on 3AW, 4BC, 2GB and 6PR While Quinnâ€™s take never appeared, the SMH and the Age did publish an extraordinary piece by Nineâ€™s political editor Chris Uhlmann the next day. Uhlmann was one on a panel of three questioners with David Crowe and Deborah Knight for the debate, which may explain this swipe at Guardian Australia: â€œIt is odd that an organ [Guardian Australia] so angrily post-Christian behaves so much like the medieval church, because it has appointed itself the guardian of the constantly shifting sands of modern virtue, and routinely conducts witch-hunts,â€ Uhlmann wrote. â€œIt is also so disconnected from Australiaâ€™s sources of wealth, food and power that it spends most of its time campaigning to shut them down.â€ Itâ€™s good to know the cartoonists are still free to express their views at the SMH and Age. Trying to follow the leaders pic.twitter.com/qnFzHjKsWW After all the criticism of Nineâ€™s debate, Seven had a roadmap for what not to do. Seven political editor Mark Riley stood close to the two leaders and kept a tight rein on them, resulting in a respectful and sober affair. The debateâ€™s numbers were slightly below Nineâ€™s, which is not surprising given the later time slot and a very poor lead-in from Big Brother, but Seven and Riley were widely praised for their efforts by gallery veterans Barrie Cassidy, Laura Tingle, David Speers and Paul Bongiorno. On the back of her views about trans women in sport, the Liberal partyâ€™s Warringah candidate Katherine Deves has become a major player in the mediaâ€™s coverage of the election campaign. Deves is the eighth-most mentioned candidate, according to media monitoring, ahead of Labor frontbenchers Penny Wong and Jason Clare and One Nation leader Pauline Hanson, and that is despite refusing most media requests for interviews. Deves did appear on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday after sitting down with normally London-based reporter Latika Bourke for a chat, in which she â€œrepeatedly burst into tearsâ€ and spoke of â€œdark momentsâ€. "Polling has shown that the overwhelming majority of Australians agree with my position on womenâ€™s sport. I would say to those other candidates theyâ€™re not reading the room."My interview with this election's most controversial candidate, Katherine Deves:https://t.co/WOKRLQJJkp The Age ran the story not on page one but inside, over two pages, under the headline â€œTears and â€˜dark momentsâ€™ but Deves fights onâ€. The Liberal candidate spelled out all the pain she has suffered since her divisive tweets were uncovered. â€œItâ€™s really debased the electoral process â€” people should be able to speak their minds and engage and put their hands up for public office without their safety or their childrenâ€™s safety put at risk,â€ Deves told the SMH. Among the criticism of Bourkeâ€™s piece is that Deves does not identify what polling she is relying on to back up her claim that the majority of Australians agree with her position on trans women in sport. â€œI would highly doubtâ€ https://t.co/102m0twaa9 In the same newspaper a day earlier, political commentator Niki Savva said senior Liberals accused Morrison of â€œabandoning progressive Liberals and using Deves to chase conservative Christians or people of other faithsâ€. The Nine papers may have helped that cause, giving Deves such sympathetic exposure a week before the polls. The Sydney Morning Herald declined to comment when approached about the story. Not long after we published our piece about Sky News presenter Paul Murray unleashing a foul-mouthed tirade against Labor at Eatons Hill Hotel in Brisbane, Murrayâ€™s 8pm show came on Sky News on Thursday evening. While Murray did not dignify us with a mention, his regular Labor party guest Nicholas Reece did. Reece, the deputy lord mayor of Melbourne city council, was aware of what Murray had said about him on Tuesday night in the leaked audio but he was happy to roll with the punches. In the audio, after Murrayâ€™s audience said they didnâ€™t like the Labor guests Reece or Stephen Conroy, Murray laughed and said Reece was like a â€œblow-up clown dollâ€, meaning he gets knocked down and always comes back for more, adding: â€œHe thinks heâ€™s doing Godâ€™s workâ€. After saying hello to Murray on Thursdayâ€™s program, Reece smiled and said he was happy to be on the show â€œdoing Godâ€™s workâ€. Murray did not bite. The Liberal party has not responded to multiple attempts by Crikey journalists to secure an invitation to its campaign launch in Brisbane on Sunday. The managing editor of Crikeyâ€™s owner Private Media, Peter Fray, is unimpressed by the cold shoulder. Crikey were fierce critics of Tony Abbott before the 2010 and 2013 campaigns, but his team had no problem with us attending events (or returning our calls). @TurnbullMalcolm's team went out of their way to ensure we had access. But persona non grata now. â€œLike all journalists, Crikey has a vested interest in seeing democracy at work,â€ Fray told Weekly Beast. â€œSure, weâ€™ve published some robust things about the PM and senior ministers. We are not alone in that. Thatâ€™s our job and thatâ€™s no reason to ban us from the Liberal launch. There is no justification for stopping us from doing our job. The PMâ€™s media team needs to remember that journalism isnâ€™t propaganda. Unless Australia has slipped from democracy to autocracy.â€ Former ABC staff have been mobilising this election, under the banner ABC Alumni, producing a series of videos encouraging people to consider the ABCâ€™s future when they vote. Former ABC chief Foreign Correspondent Phil Williams highlights the importance of having an Australian perspective for an Australian audience when reporting from overseas. #vote1ABC pic.twitter.com/sqyvPspO9v In his video on the threat to democracy, Kerry Oâ€™Brien warns that public broadcasting is vital to a healthy democracy, as footage of the US Capitol riots played behind him. But it was a video from former chief foreign correspondent Philip Williams, filmed at his rural retreat, which attracted the ire of the ABC. The ABC asked the alumni to remove several screenshots of ABC correspondents from the video as they breached rules on the use of ABC content in election advertising. We understand the original complaint came from the Liberal party, but the ABC declined to confirm.
column4: Nine mutes one of its own critics after shouty leadersâ€™ debate | The Weekly Beast
